name: Gavin
comment info: You are leaving out an entire half of our system. You are missing how the senate relates to the house of representatives. While yes, smaller states have more power in the senate, larger states have more power in the house of representatives. This is because we have a bicameral house that favors both smaller states and larger states. If you were to effectively remove the smaller states power and base vote power off of population in the senate, you might as well have just one house of representatives. It would mess up the balance of power and smaller states would have no choice but to do what the larger states ask. Rather this bicameral system finds the best of both worlds by making sure both population and small states both agree on a bill before passing it. No change is needed.

comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph displays the ratios of the number of voters that are represented by each Senator for six states.  For example, each senator from Connecticut represents 6 times as many voters as does the senator from Wyoming. 

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?”, “What do you wonder?"  and “How will this affect you?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these “graphs.” We look forward to replying to your discoveries.

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the online article that included this infographic.  

Note that you can get a link to your response (and replies made to it) to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, Nov. 11 with moderation on Wednesday, Nov. 16.  The topic – college professional athletes.

name: Ashley Alv. (P5)
comment info:
I observe that the number of representatives varies depending on the size of the state. For instance, Michigan is a smaller state with only 18 voters, whereas California is a major state with 59 voters. name: I.B.
comment info:
It takes about 21 white voters in California to equal one white voter in Wyoming or in North Dakota. There is no comparison of white voters in Wyoming to voters of any other race in North Dakota -- are their votes so small they are negligible? In addition, I notice that although some states have higher numbers of voters than others, the proportion of white, black, Hispanic, or other voters in these states are different. 
Then again, the word 'Hispanic' is doing a lot of work here. 'Hispanic' does not function as a racial category in the way that 'black' or 'white' does -- there are white Hispanics and black Hispanics, for example. Why not consolidate these groups into their respective racial categories, and keep separate those Hispanics who do not fall under either white or black? 
One other thing I wonder about is that these counts are based off of populations, and not necessarily voter turnout. I think about this because in a number of these states there are many restrictions to voting (that often affect BIPOC people disproportionately to white people) that could drastically affect these figures. What proportion of the black voters in California are in prison? What proportion of the indigenous voters in North Dakota cannot vote due to a lack of photo identification? This figure does not answer these questions.
In my state, the carceral system is majorly made up of blacks and Hispanics. These people cannot vote -- the population of Florida doesn't represent them.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @I.B. --

Oh, do you bring up many of these issues about the data behind these ratios.  

The graph says “voters” but it also refers to population and representation.  I wonder, too, which data was used in calculating this infographic.  Was it state populations?  Adults 18 years and older who are citizens (and can, therefore, vote)?  Registered voters?  What year was used?  2020 – the year of the last U.S. Census? 2022 – this election year?  What do you think?

Every decade, the U.S. Census grapples with how to divide the population among groups.  In the end, the census asks respondents to self-identify race and ethnicity.  In 2020, there were many categories including “two or more races” and “Some Other Race.”  Online, you can read about how this was done for the 2020 U.S. Census, including how they differentiate groups of Hispanics.
